greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Maximum digit in the factorial base expansion of n (A007623).
comment: Maximum entry in n-th row of A108731.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10080
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
example: Factorial base representation of 46 is "1320" as 46 = 1*4! + 3*3! + 2*2! + 0*1!, and the largest of these digits is 3, thus a(46) = 3.
mathematica: nn = 96; m = 1; While[Factorial@ m < nn, m++]; m; Table[Max@ IntegerDigits[n, MixedRadix[Reverse@ Range[2, m]]], {n, 0, nn}] (* Version 10.2, or *)

f[n_] := Block[{a = {{0, n}}}, Do[AppendTo[a, {First@ #, Last@ #} &@ QuotientRemainder[a[[-1, -1]], Times @@ Range[# - i]]], {i, 0, #}] &@ NestWhile[# + 1 &, 0, Times @@ Range[# + 1] <= n &]; Most@ Rest[a][[All, 1]] /. {} -> {0}]; Table[Max@ f@ n, {n, 0, 96}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Aug 29 2016 *)
program: (MIT/GNU Scheme) (define (A246359 n) (let loop ((n n) (i 2) (md 0)) (if (zero? n) md (loop (floor->exact (/ n i)) (+ i 1) (max (modulo n i) md)))))
def a007623(n, p=2): return n if n
print([a(n) for n in range(101)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jun 21 2017
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 20 2014
